Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A platform for identifying antibodies that modulate human membrane receptors involved in disease
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to enable the discovery of needed antibody therapeutics in diseases for which there are no available treatments. These therapies act by increasing or decreasing the activity of a type of cell signaling receptor, "G protein-coupled receptors" (GPCRs). Antibodies are highly specific for their targets, an important characteristic for GPCR drugs, as GPCRs comprise a large family of structurally similar proteins. In fact, small molecule drugs for GPCRs often are toxic due to side effects from acting on structurally similar but functionally unrelated GPCRs. This project will develop the first technology that directly identifies antibodies by their ability to modulate GPCR function. These antibodies will impact society's health by treating currently incurable diseases, and strongly impact scientific understanding by enabling the study of GPCR-related mammalian physiology and disease. The commercial impacts are potentially very large. The global GPCR drug market is over $100B, and over half of marketed antibody therapeutics have annual sales of over $1B. The platform described here has the potential to develop many GPCR antibody therapeutics, and thereby generate an enormous amount of value for patients, society at large, and co-development partners.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop a platform for discovering GPCR-modulating antibodies. This platform could be critical for generating tools for studying GPCR-related biology and disease, and for developing therapeutics with fewer side effects than small molecule drugs to treat GPCR-related diseases. Developing functional GPCR antibodies using traditional methods is encumbered by the difficulty in producing antigens that represent the GPCR in a functional state, and a lack of high-throughput assays of GPCR function. The proposed platform and method expresses human GPCRs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae yeast, couples activity to selectable phenotypes, and directly selects antibodies that modulate GPCR function in the same cells. The first objective aims to further characterize the activity and specificity of camelid antibodies ("nanobodies") antagonists that inhibit the endogenous yeast GPCR, Ste2, and then perform agonist selections to identify at least one Ste2 agonist. The second objective aims to further develop the platform to enable interrogating a broader array of human GPCR targets using ScFv antibody libraries, and to identify at least one agonist or antagonist of a therapeutically relevant human GPCR. Positive results will demonstrate the feasibility of the platform.

Institution.Name: Abalone Bio, Inc.
Institution.StreetAddress: 2600 Hilltop Dr, Bldg B Rm C332

POR.DRECONTENT:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to (1) facilitate the discovery of needed antibody therapeutics in diseases for which there are no adequate treatments and (2) to isolate an antibody therapeutic candidate for chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN). This class of antibody therapies acts by increasing or decreasing the activity of a type of cell signaling receptor, "G protein-coupled receptors" (GPCRs). Antibodies are highly specific for their targets, an important requirement in GPCR drugs, because these receptors comprise a large family of structurally similar proteins. In fact, small molecule drugs for GPCRs often are toxic because they act on functionally unrelated GPCRs that are structurally similar to their target. This project developed and demonstrated the first technology that directly identifies antibodies by their ability to modulate GPCR function. In addition, we isolated an antibody candidate that can reduce pain and opioid addiction in CIPN. Antibody therapies for GPCRs will impact society's health as novel therapeutics for poorly treated diseases; they will also advance our scientific understanding of GPCR function in physiology and disease. The commercial impacts are potentially very large. The global GPCR drug market is over $100B; over half of marketed antibody therapeutics have annual sales of over $1B. An antibody therapy for CIPN can provide relief to vast numbers of patients. In addition, this platform has the potential to generate many other GPCR antibody therapeutics—an enormous value proposition for patients, co-development partners, and society at large.

 

This SBIR Phase I project developed a platform for discovering GPCR-modulating antibodies. This platform is critical for generating antibody tools for studying GPCR-related biology and disease, and for developing antibody therapeutics with fewer side effects than small molecule drugs to treat GPCR-related diseases. Developing functional GPCR antibodies using traditional methods is encumbered by the difficulty in producing antigens that represent the functional structure of the GPCR. The new platform developed in this project expresses human GPCRs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae yeast, couples their activity to selectable phenotypes, and directly selects antibodies that modulate GPCR function in the same cells that produce the antibodies. We demonstrated the platform by isolating camelid antibody ("nanobody") agonists for the human cannabinoid receptor 2 (CB2), a GPCR involved in modulating pain and opioid addiction in CIPN. We identified two unrelated nanobodies that specifically activate CB2 in the yeast platform. We produced one of these agonist antibodies as a recombinant protein and assessed its function on human cells stably transfected to overexpress either human or mouse CB2 or rat CB1 (hCB2, mCB2, rCB1). The nanobody agonist had potent agonist activity on internalization assays (hCB2 EC50 ~25 nM, mCB2 ~20 nM) and adenylate cyclase inhibition assays (hCB2 ~10 nM, mCB2 ~2 nM). It had no activity in either assay on hCB1. These promising findings have now set the stage for our Phase II work.

 


Last Modified: 02/01/2019
Modified by: Gustavo Pesce

Antibodies are highly specific for their targets, an important requirement in GPCR drugs, because these receptors comprise a large family of structurally similar proteins. This project developed and demonstrated the first technology that directly identifies antibodies by their ability to modulate GPCR function. In addition, we isolated an antibody candidate that can reduce pain and opioid addiction in CIPN. In addition, this platform has the potential to generate many other GPCR antibody therapeutics—an enormous value proposition for patients, co-development partners, and society at large.
